text: Raking down a line of suburban gardens lit by a late-summ sun. Heads move back and forth above the fences that divi the narrow strips of land, moving to the sound of unseen lawn mowers. In one of these gardens two children, BILL (aged eight) a his sister SUE (aged six) disport themselves. They are sprawled out on the lawn, heads and hands intent on something hidden from view in the lush vegetation of a rockery garden. Beneath those flowers and plants is a dar and mysterious forest, shaded by huge leaves, and broken by towering boulders. Mounted figures of medieval knights ride in, guided by BILL'S gigantic hand. A wizard appears in the path of the riders who draw up sharply. BILL gives an impression of neighing horses. SUE'S face looms up between large leaves. She makes the sound of spooky wind.

In the penumbra of the room, the mother, GRACE, in droopy flowered frock, crosses, floats towards the walnut wirele and, with trembling hand, switches it on. Its green dial glows with stations like Droitwich and Hilversum. She glides back and drapes herself behind an armchair in whic her husband, CLIVE, sits solemn and motionless.

The sound of the lawn-mower ceases abruptly. BILL looks u sharply. The neighbours' heads come to rest on top of the garden fences. They turn, listening. BILL inclines his he towards the french windows, sensing the dread moment. He walks towards the door and is framed there. He regards hi parents.
They look back with unseeing, inward-turned eyes. Young BILL gathers confused fragments of the fateful announcement.
...those assurances... by eleven o'clock... a state of war... that this country... at war with Germany.
The boy catches his mother's eye. She smiles en embarrass smile. The boy is embarrassed by her embarrassment. His father's glassy solemnity angers him. In the garden, SUE sings.
(singing) Flat foot floogie with a Floy Floy.
BILL turns to his sister.
Stop that, Sue!
CLIVE is startled out of his funereal reverie.
She just sings it. She doesn't know what it means.
An older sister, DAWN, a tumescent fifteen, stumbles into the room in a nightdress.
Where are my stockings? I can't find my stockings!
Her mother, GRACE, interrupts her with outstretched arms.
Dawn, darling. They've started a war again.
GRACE says it as though announcing that dinner is served, but her voice is torn by a sob as she holds DAWN in her arms.
(Whispering and sobbing) We mustn't frighten the little ones.
DAWN is appalled by her mother's display of sentiment. Sh wrenches free.
I don't care! I want my stockings!
CLIVE get's up, blazing. He seizes DAWN and shakes her.
Stockings? War! Don't you understand! War!
I don't care!
War! War!
GRACE inserts herself between them.
Clive. Don't. Dawn, please.
BILL calls out from the garden. He is jumping up and down pointing at the sky.
German planes! German planes!
They run out. GRACE sweeps little SUE into her arms, buri her face in her bosom and rushing back into the shelter o the house. DAWN and CLIVE scan the sky for planes, There are none.
I did see them. I did.
He's the worst liar.
DAWN swings a fist at BILL and chases him inti the room, raining savage blows upon him.
Father is white with rage. He seizes them, one in each hand. Mother cowers with SUE.
These are the fruits of my loins?
DAWN lunges at BILL. The GRANDMOTHER enters, tall, frail, elegant, ga-ga, deaf.
Is it peace in out time?
(shouting) No, Mother! It's War! War!
Or what?
War! War! War!

The wireless begins to play 'God Save the King'. Father immediately lets go of the children and stands rigidly to attention. The others simmer down and shuffle into stiff and still poses. GRANDMOTHER, who perhaps cannot hear the Anthem, i baffled, shakes her head.

The sirens sound. A shocking blast of noises, the sickeni ululations of the air-raid warning. They call out over th rows of bow-fronted semi-detached, lower-middle-class houses. Some of the occupants, more daring or more confus than their neighbours, burst out of their front doors, turning in frenzied circles, craning at the heavens.

The rigid family once more jerks into movement at the sou of the siren, looking forcefully out of the french window hiding under the table, clutching each other. The siren stops. They wait, anxiously. Silence. Even the birds stopped singing at the wailing of the first siren. This w perhaps the worst moment of the war, the first moment, wh war was still an unknown dread thing. The siren again, bu this time, a long sustained note.
That's the all-clear. Testing. They were just testing.
CLIVE walks tentatively into the garden, looking up, shielding his eyes against the sun. The others join Him, one by one.
Such a beautiful day too.
All search the clear blue sky. The sound of the lawn-mowe starts up again where it left off before the war.
(singing) Flat Foot Floogie with a Floy Floy.

A Ministry of Information film advises and demonstrates h to glue strips of paper to windows to avoid flying glass, and how to construct an air-raid shelter. On the soundtrack, in addition to the patronizing commentary voice, is the sound of hundreds of screaming children. BILL and SUE sit among the children's matinee audience. T children pay no attention to the screen, but fight and shout, throw things at each other, jump over seats, cry, wander up and down the aisles. The soundtrack changes to dramatic music and a transformation takes place. All movement and talking ceases. Hundreds of rapt faces stare at the screen where Hopalong Cassidy rides into action.
CLIVE has put an Anderson shelter at the end of the small garden, He is shovelling earth on to its humped corrugate metal roof. His friend, MAC, is watching him.
Going to put a rockery garden over it, Mac.
BILL's voice echoes from inside the shelter.
Dad. It's full of water again.
CLIVE and MAC peer in to see the boy splashing up and dow water over his ankles. He clutches his submerged foot in mock agony.
Crocodiles! Aah!
The sodding water table.
Could you seal it over with hot pitch, Clive? Caulk it like the hull of a ship.
(caustic) Thanks. I hope you can come for the launching.

The windows are criss-crossed with brown paper. Beyond, i the garden, MAC has taken off his jacket and is shovellin earth onto the shelter. BILL walks barefoot towards the house, carrying his wet socks and shoes in his hands.
It's not fair on them. It's selfish to keep them with you.
My aunt in Australia has offered..
BILL sits on the steps at the half-open kitchen door and wrings the water from his socks. SUE comes in and GRACE signals MOLLY to be circumspect, but she blunders on.
Snap it up. Great chance for them. Lot more future out there.
BILL listens, talking it all in. GRACE Watches little SUE waddle out carrying planes.
It's so far way. I couldn't bear it.
Kids don't care. You're thinking of yourself.
GRACE turns away. Fighting back tears. MOLLY impulsively takes GRACE in her arms.
I didn't mean it like that, Grace. Why does it always come out wrong?
I know you mean well.
MOLLY laughs and holds her at arms length.
There you go again. You're so bloody nice. I want to shake you.
She does, mock serious.
Nothing will ever be the same again, Molly. And the funny thing is, I'm glad.
MOLLY looks at her, surprised.
Now you're talking.
SUE listening to this, sees BILL on the steps and gives h a questioning look. He shrugs, trying to conceal his anxiety from his sister.

DAWN lies in bed, head buried in pillows in that deepest all sleep, the Sunday morning adolescent lie-in. BILL shakes her, jumps on top of her, imitates an air-raid warning, tries to pull off the bedclothes but she holds them tight.
There's a soldier at he door, looking for you.
She whips back the sheet, wide awake. One look at his fac is enough to see that he is lying.
You're the biggest fibber.
It's dinner time. It really is. Cross my heart.
She snakes out an arm and pulls him into bed. She rolls o top of him, tickling him and smothering him with kisses.
If there's no solider, I'll have you instead.
He giggles and struggles, gets into a panic, but she is merciless, won't stop. Finally he starts to cry. She leap out of bed, disgusted with him.
Cry baby Bunting.
CLIVE rummages in the wardrobe, chuckling to himself. He finds his Sam Browne belt and Army cap from the First Wol War.
MOLLY and GRACE and GRANDMA have 'gin and its', the men brown ale. They are in high spirits. SUE is doing a puzzl on the floor. MOLLY shouts into GRANDMA'S ear.
Few bombs might wake up this country.
GRACE fills MAC'S glass in a tender gesture. A look passe between them. MOLLY is a friend and wife, they love and suffer in common. DAWN appears, wearing a defiant slash o lipstick.
I doubt if a few bombs would wake up Dawn on a Sunday morning.
This phoney war get's on my nerves. If we're going to have a war, I wish they'd get it started.
Just ignore her, Mac.

CLIVE appears having stripped to the waist but wearing hi Sam Browne from the First Wold War. They all shriek with laughter. CLIVE, encouraged by this response, does drill movements and then demonstrates how to salute.
There are many ways of saluting.. (He demonstrates.) ..An old soldier insulting a young subaltern.
His hand flies to his forehead, gouging the air, the salu transformed into an obscene gesture. More laughter.
As an officer, you counter that with one of these.

He raises his arm slowly and languidly until his limp han just brushes his temple. A faraway look in his eyes disdains any acknowledgement of the insulting salute. A tiny skirmish in the class war. BILL and SUE swing on the leather straps of the Sam Brown They want him to stop. They sense something dangerous, alien, their father in an unfamiliar role, another person The wireless has been on all this time, playing music and now come the chimes of Big Ben. It is news time. The adul are suddenly stock-still and serious, leaving the childre stranded in an excited state..
Here is the news and this is Alvar Lidell reading it.
The children are told to be quiet. The room becomes a frieze of portentous concentration.
BILL slips into the garden, looks up at the leaden sky imploringly.
Come on. Come on.
The news bulletin filters out into the garden. Norway has fallen, perhaps, or Churchill become Prime Minister.

The meal has been eaten. They are animated again, but mor reflective, DAWN is winding wool with GRANDMA. BILL and S have also left the table. BILL is looking at the Sam Browne, now slung over the armchair, with its tangy smell of deep polish like shiny milk chocolate, a mysterious ic of war. The conversation at the table drifts over to him.
...It was a toss-up. His company went to India, mine went to France. Flip of a coin.
...two Indians to fan me all night. The heat.
....buried In a shell-hole for thee days, while he's out there playing polo and sticking pigs.
It was the best time of his life.
How many of our class left? You and me out of twenty-eight.
And Jim.
What's left of him. He'll never see outside of the Star and Garter.
BILL sinks his teeth into Same Browne. He bites hard and pleased to see that his teeth marks go quite deep into th leather.
I rode into battle...
DAWN, winding wool, knows this speech by heart and mimes silently with her father.
...On horseback, with a drawn sword, leading a battalion of Gurkhas against the Turks.
GRANDMA watches DAWN'S moving lips and strains to hear.
I can't hear you.
And where were the Turks?
She also knows the story.
No Turks.
We didn't know that. It was a suicide mission. Machetes against artillery. Volunteers only.
They'd gone.
Saw Clive coming.

They all have a good laugh at CLIVE'S expense and he take it well enough. BILL drifts over to his lead soldiers spread out in a corner of the room. They are an eclectic mix of cowboys, Indians, the Medieval Knights, as well as modern militia and a few farm animals.
We all had to write a last letter home.
And it was the last. Hasn't written a letter since. Not even a birthday card.
BILL sets a mounted knight against a clutch of modern infantry.
It's not like when you're in it. Just young boys spilling their guts in the mud.
What were they like, the Germans, when you were a prisoner of war?
BILL looks up with interest. The others fall silent.
Most of them were very decent to me.
I wish you wouldn't go saying that. You'll get into trouble.
You can speak German, can't you?
A bit.
Say something. I want to know what it sounds like.
Certainly not!
In den ganzen Welt die meisten Leute sind dumm.
Not so loud!

Later. The two men are in post-prandial sleep in the armchairs on either side of the fire. Sounds of washing u and women's voices come from the kitchen. BILL walks up very close and examines the two warriors from the Great War, or the First Wold War, as it was now coming to be known. Their mouths are open, slack. His father's false teeth click up and down as he breathes. MAC shifts his backside in his sleep to let a fart up from the side of t leatherette armchair. BILL looks at CLIVE's mottled skin, the stubble, the sagging epidermis around the eyes. He go to the mantelpiece and takes down a silver-framed picture of his father as a baby-faced second lieutenant wearing that same Sam Browne. BILL holds the picture next to his father's snoring face. Once again, a new bulletin begins the ever-playing wireless.
Dad, the News. It's the News.
CLIVE stirs.
Go off and play, son.
BILL shakes him.
But Dad, It's the News.
Thanks, son. I can hear it. I'm not sleeping, just closing my eyes.
BILL is confused. He still feels it is his duty to wake him.
(shouting) The Germans! They've landed!
GRACE and MOLLY appear at the door, alarmed. The men slee on.
Only joking.

BILL and SUE are in two beds, side by side. Between them a crystal set and they are sharing the earphones listenin to Itma or Much Binding in the Marsh. Their door is half open and a gust of shots and cries rises from below. BILL gets up and goes to the door.
BILL and SUE venture out on to the landing and peer throu the banisters to the hallway and front door below.
MAC and MOLLY are leaving, as CLIVE and GRACE help them o with their coats. They have had a few more drinks, and ar making sentimental farewells.
Bloody gin. Always makes me cry.
Got some wires crossed. Only weeps when she's happy.
You're making me start now.
MAC embarrasses her.
Now, now Grace.
He turns to CLIVE and takes him by the shoulders. They ar both quiet drunk.
Root it out Clive... the thought of it, before it takes hold.
Weeds will grow, Mac.
Consider Grace, the kids. I love them like my own. And you.
Kiss me Hardy.
As he mentions the children Molly wails anew.
Why couldn't I have the kids? Is he sitting up there... saying... "Grace, yes; Molly, no?"
GRACE holds her tight.
Better off, Molly. What's to become of the poor mites!
SUE'S face creases and tears well up. BILL puts a protective arm about her.
You're a mug, Clive. We did our bit in the Last Lot.
If King and Country call, Mac, you go as soon as I will.
MAC'S face goes white with anger.
What did we know? We were seventeen.
(with a far-off look) I heard the drum and fife yesterday, Mac, marching past. Made my hair stand on end. I thought, I've been asleep for twenty years.
MAC wants to hit him. He turns away, trembling.
Go the Hell.
He puts an arm about MOLLY and plunges into the blacked-o dark-winter-night. As GRACE turns back, she glimpses the children on the landing above.
Do you know what time it is? Go back to bed, this instant.
They dart out of sight.
BILL and SUE slide under the bedclothes. SUE is whimperin
We're not going to be like them when we grow up. We're not even like them now.
He picks up the earphones and twiddles with the crystal wireless. It is the News again. BILL fiddles with the lea soldiers, his eyes getting heavy.

Infantry advance as shells bust all about them. CLIVE and MAC push forward, side by side. MAC is hit, goes down, cries out for help, but CLIVE does not seem to notice. A muddy field. Silence. Aftermath of battle. BILL searche among the dead. They are half-buried, covered in mud, all one texture with the earth. BILL finds CLIVE and MAC, lyi side by side, dead. He is quite unconcerned, pulls his father's Sam Browne which slips off easily. He wipes the mud away and starts to eat it. It seems to be made of chocolate.

A 1938 Vauxhall 12 is parked outside a recruiting centre. boisterous crowd of young men mills about, passing in and out, encouraging each other, cheering each new man who steps out a soldier. Next door is a pub and there is a continuous exchange of customers between the two establishments. BILL and SUE wa inside the car. She is whining in the back, sucking her thumb. BILL sits in the driving seat, pretending to drive making all the right noises.
He's never going to come back. He's gone off to be a soldier and Mummy doesn't even know.
It doesn't matter, I can drive the car home.
You wouldn't.
Would.
You couldn't.
Could.
CLIVE, arm in arm with a PAL, comes out of the pub and ov to the car. He gets in after much handshaking and back slapping.
Sorry, kids. Joined up. I needed some Dutch courage to tell your mother.
The PAL opens the passenger door and leans in.
Never say die!
Steady the Buffs.
Up the Arsenal!
CLIVE leans across and slams the door closed. The PAL wav at the window. CLIVE pulls away. The PAL runs alongside, waving. CLIVE laughs and waves back.
He's one of the best.
Still the PAL keeps up with the car, running frantically.
Daddy you shut his hand in the door.
The PAL jumps on the running board and crouches there, re faced, eyes bulging. He waves desperately at the window.
The silly bugger.
He pulls up the and opens the door. The PAL clasps his ha and writhes in agony.
You silly bugger. We're trying to win a war and you start off by shutting your fingers in the bloody car door.
CLIVE is putting the car on blocks, taking off the wheels BILL helps him.
That's it for the duration. (runs a duster over the bodywork) I shall miss the old girl. Pop in and give her a polish, Billy boy. Just now and then. A car needs to be cherished.
GRACE has appeared at the door and heard some of this.
Has Sue got it right?
What's that?
You joined up.
Oh, that.
I wish you could have told me yourself. (he takes Grace in his arms.) Oh, Grace, it's not for long. They say it'll be over by Christmas.
CLIVE laughs and tickles her, trying to get round her, ke it light. GRACE laughs despite herself. BILL makes a face disgusted by the show of sentiment.
Don't be so daft. Act your age. (extricates herself) I can't cope on my own. I'd better let the children go.
CLIVE leads BILL out on to the lawn, goes down on one kne and puts his hand on the boy's shoulder. He looks solemnl into his son's eyes.

Billy boy. Before I go, there's something I want to tell you. You're old enough now. It's time. (produces a cricket ball from his pocket.) The Googly. Your hand is too small to master it, but not to start practising. Anyway, I'm going to pass on the secret now, father to son, in case anything happens to me. (demonstrates) You know the off-break, right?
He flicks the ball out of his wrist. BILL nods.
And the leg-break?
BILL knows that too. The ball comes out of his hand, spinning the other way.
Now, the googly looks like a leg break, but it's really an off break. Got it? Like this.
It's like telling fibs.

That's it. When you tell a lie, you hope to get away with it. When someone else does, you want to find them out. A good batsman will spot a googly. A good bowler will hide it. Always remember that, son.
BILL flicks the ball this way and that, experimenting. CLIVE watches him tenderly, a moment of perfect harmony. folds BILL in his arms, holding him fast.
BILL swings on the front gate looking back at his mother, SUE and DAWN bidding their farewells to CLIVE in a confusion of tears and forced gaiety.
CLIVE finally strides away, head high, a military spring already in his step. Behind him GRACE shuts the door as though closing a chapter of their lives.
Dad! Dad!

CLIVE, now some twenty yards away, looks back. BILL throw the cricket ball and CLIVE catches it neatly. He smiles a marches down Rosehill Avenue. BILL is puzzled as CLIVE shows no sign of returning the ball. He calls after him.
Dad!

CLIVE is now eighty yards down the street. He suddenly turns smiling broadly, and with a prodigious throw he sen the ball in a high arc towards his son. BILL juggles his position, cups his hands, gets under it as the hard, heav ball hurtles downwards. At the last moment he loses his nerve and jumps back, letting the ball thump onto the law He looks towards CLIVE, full of shame. BILL is relieved t see that CLIVE has turned the corner.

BILL winces as he and SUE are passed from hand to hand, hugged and kissed by many female members of the family - DAWN, GRANDMA and GRACE'S three sisters, FAITH, HOPE and CHARITY. MOLLY is on hand with MAC, the only male. On the table are the remains of the farewell party, an iced cake balloons, gaudy wrapping paper. Encouraging cries fly about. "Aren't you lucky?" "Isn't it exciting?" "I wish I could hide in your suitcase." From the smothering embrace BILL casts a pleading look to MAC who reaches out and hau him from the women.
You survived that. The war should be no problem.
GRACE ties a label to BILL'S lapel. It declares his name and other details.
Time to go.
She leads the children out MAC follows, carrying two suitcases.

MAC and GRACE lead BILL and SUE into the concourse where hundreds of children are assembled, each wearing an identification label. The noise is overwhelming. The organizers shout into megaphones. One buy has fainted and is put on a stretcher by St. Johns Ambulance men and, to get through the crowd, they hold the stretcher above thei heads. The boy recovers, sits up and waves to his friends The parents throng behind the barrier and they follow him WOMEN'S VOLUNTARY SERVICE (W.V.S) Volunteers stand by.
Australia?
GRACE nods. The W.V.S WOMAN examines the labels on SUE an BILL and checks them against her list. The steam ad noise have suffocating effect on GRACE.
Say goodbye and pass them through.
GRACE weeps as she embraces SUE. BILL fights back the tea and turns away embarrassed when his mother wants a kiss from him.
I'm going to miss the war and it's all your fault.

They are sucked into the enclosure and quickly disappear among the throng of refugee children. GRACE tries to foll with her eyes, searching for them hungrily. They disappea MAC flinches at the pain he sees in her face. She lunges forward, and tries to push through the barrier.
I can't do it. What's the point?
It's just the wrench, Grace. It's for their sake.
He tries to restrain her, but she breaks free.
Let me through, I want my children.
No one goes in there. You signed the forms, didn't you?
Yes, I did. And now I want them back.
Too late. Plenty of others would've been glad of their places.

The W.V.S. WOMAN and an ARP MAN are forcibly holding her. MAC cannot bear to watch her pain. He leaps over the barrier, grans SUE and BILL and hoists them out of the pe BILL is acutely embarrassed at the scene his mother is making. He struggles to get free of MAC.
Let me alone. I want to go. I want to go.

MAC swings them over to GRACE. She snatches up SUE and hu her. Over the child's shoulder her eye is drawn to a post depicting a ghostly Hitler hovering over a mother and her children. He whispers in her ear "Take them back".
In front of everybody. They were all looking at us. Why did you have to do it?
GRACE is shattered, drained. She becomes calm almost dreamy.
Please yourself. (turns to Mac) Let them go, if they want.
Grace!
GRACE turns back to the barrier, which is still defended the W.V.S WOMAN with the clipboard.
Changed your mind?
Yes.
Well, you're too late. Apply again. On your head be it.

BILL glues balsa wood wings on to a model Spitfire. Opposite him, across the dining-room table, GRACE is cutting something out of the newspaper. DAWN'S school boo are spread out on the table, but she has abandoned them i favour of a dancing lesson by Victor Sylvester on the wireless. She steers her imaginary partner between the furniture, her face concentrates, trying to follow the steps.
Slow, quick, quick, slow. Right forward.. left together.. Three, four.. Back together.. Turn.. One, two.. Quick, quick, slow.
GRACE crosses the room towards the kitchen. DAWN passes i from of her and she falls into step partnering her daught in the dance.
You know it? It must be an old one.
Ancient. Have you finished your homework?
After this dance.
She mouths the steps, "Forward..quick, quick, slow"

GRACE pins the newspaper cutting to a bulletin board whic also displays a 'war map' with pins in it showing the progress of hostilities. The cutting is a David Low carto showing a soldier standing defiantly on a rocky promontor looking across a stormy sea towards France, saying 'Very well alone.' She is deeply moved by it. BILL enters and watches her, sensitive of her mood, but he has a mournful duty. He takes out the pins, representing the German Army in Russia.
I've got to move the Germans to Minsk. They've taken Minsk.
GRACE lays a restraining hand on his shoulder.
Tomorrow. Give them one more night of freedom. Move them in the morning.

Swirling to the dance music, DAWN comes face to face with the clock on the mantelpiece and registers the hours. She dives for the wireless and searches for another station. She is satisfied when she hears the stenorian tones of Lo Haw-Haw's nightly propaganda broadcast from Germany.
Quick! Lord Haw-Haw! He's starting.
BILL scampers in. GRACE hovers by the door.

..the soldiers like to wager among themselves, what day will the German army enter Moscow? One thing is certain: much sooner than anyone thought. From here in Berlin, listeners in Britain, I can give some very definite news. There will be a bomber raid on London tonight, the fourteenth night in succession. Look out for bombs if you live in Carshalton or Croydon. There will be incendiary attacks if you live in Fulham and Hammersmith. And watch out in Kew; be alert in Walthamstow.
BILL looks at his mother, DAWN gets up and goes over to t wireless, staring at it.
That's us.
It's just German Propaganda.
He always knows.
Half the time he's bluffing.
A moment of dread hangs over the room. GRACE summons her resolve and bustles over to the wireless and snaps it off
Bill, off to bed.
She gives him a shove towards the door to silence his protest. She takes DAWN by the shoulder and presses her into a chair and pushes her head into her homework.

Sirens are sounding, one after the other, some distant, some close, then the one at the end of the street, like dogs howling in the night waking other dogs. Three German bombers, a Heinkel, a Dornier and a Stuka, fly in formati across the black sky. GRACE appears behind the model planes, which hang on threads from the ceiling, wakes BIL and SUE and they stumble out of bed.
GRACE leads BILL and SUE down the stairs. They sleep on their feet in this familiar routine. DAWN is still dresse below, playing dance records on the gramophone and finishing homework.
We better go to the shelter.
They open the French windows and fierce wind cuts into th room.
It's freezing out.
GRACE hesitates, then closes the windows.

They squeeze themselves into the tiny space under the stairs, close the door and light a candle. BILL and SUE complain irritably as they try to arrange their limbs. Th shoving and pushing wakes them up. GRACE gives each of them a biscuit from a tin.
What would we do if a German came into the house?
Don't be silly, Dawn.
Well, why do you always bring the carving knife in here?

DAWN picks up the knife, pretending to hear someone outsi the cupboard door. She presses her ear to the thin wooden partition. BILL'S eyes bulge. He is half convinced. Even GRACE looks uneasy. SUE, reacting automatically to crisis pulls on her red and white 'Mickey Mouse' gasmask. Sudden DAWN thrusts the knife through a crack in the boards. She makes a blood curdling cry. GRACE slaps her, amused, despite herself. BILL seizes DAW from behind and pulls her back on top of him. They writhe and giggle. BILL cocks an ear.
Flak!

They are stock-still, straining to hear. He is right. The anti-aircraft guns have started up. Their crisp 'crump' sound gets closer and more frequent. Another separate sou intrudes - falling bombs. The explosions are at regular intervals, each one louder than the last.
Basket bombing Counts between the bombs Two and three and four and five and six and..
The next bomb falls closer.
Why didn't I take you to the shelter?
Her hands tough and caress the children, as though weavin a protective charm over them.
...four and five and six and...
Another, louder still. They sit tense and straining every muscle, willing the bombs away.
If only I'd let you go to Australia.
...and five and six and...
It is deafening, shaking the house.
The next one is ours. Either it hits us or it goes past us.
...and four and five...
Please God. Not on us. Drop it on Mrs. Evans. She's a cow.
...and six...
It drops, some way past them. They slump exhausted agains each other. A fire-engine bell approaches. The flask goes on. DAWN gets up, untangles herself from the others.
I'm not going to die like a rat in a trap. Let me out of here.
Staggers out of the cupboard.
I'm going outside.
BILL scrambles after her.
Wait. Don't.

DAWN runs out. Searchlights criss-cross the sky. Anti aircraft shells make little white puffs in the black sky, the sound coming much later. Up the road, a house is blazing. A fire engine swings by. ARP MEN run in the street. DAWN dances in the tiny front garden.
Quick, quick.. slow, quick, slow.
BILL hesitates in the porch.
It's lovely. Lovely. Does little Billy want to see the fireworks?
BILL runs out, sees something by the kerb and picks it up
Shrapnel! And it's still hot.

Come in at once, or I wash my hands of you.
A shell bursts right overhead and they duck into the open doorway. The four of them are framed there, looking up at the savage sky where the Battle of Britain rages. BILL watches enraptured.
St. Paul's sites at the heart of the blazing city.

DAWN, in school uniform, rides off on her bicycle. BILL a SUE come out with satchels and gasmasks. GRACE watches th making their way along the street scarred and damaged by the night's bombing. Late! My study before prayers.

Inspects his troops.
Now quick march. Left... right... left... right. Swing those arms.
BILL flinches and winces as the cane strikes his hand.
The children are praying, eyes closed, hands joined. On t dais, the teachers, mostly women, are lined up.
Oh God, bring destruction to our enemies. Make these young one's true soldiers of the Lord. Guide Mr. Churchill's hand in the cunning war.

Some of the boy's covertly swap pieces of shrapnel and cigarette cards as the HEADMASTER'S tirade grows in passion, but BILL is mesmerized and fearful of this daily rhetoric. He blows on his hands, shakes them to alleviate the pain inflicted by the caning.
Let our righteous shells smite down the Messerschmitts and the Fokkers.
BILL'S face, twisted in anxious anticipation, awaits the next blow.
Lord, send troublesome dreams to Herr Hitler. Let him not sleep the sleep of the innocent. And comfort our warriors at the fronts. Brighten their swords, burnish their bullets with your fire.
BILL jerks convulsively and grins as the cane connects.
The HEADMASTER reaches a climatic peak, then is silent, head sinking to his chest. He continues, very quietly.
We beseech Thee, Oh Lord, to have mercy on these Thy children.
BILL suffers another whack.
We dedicate our studies this day to the war effort.

Pink... pink... pink... pink... What are the pink bits, Rohan?

They're ours, Miss.
Yes, the British Empire.

A boy, HARPER, sits in front row and is in saliva range. Each time the TEACHER turns back to the blackboard, the b wipes his desk flamboyantly with a cloth, much to the spluttering amusement of his classmates.
Harper, what fraction of the earth's surface is British?
Don't know, Miss.
Anyone?
A girl shoots up her hand. JENNIFER BAKER.
Two-fifths, Miss.
Yes. Two-fifths. Ours. And that's what the war is all about. Men are fighting and dying to save the pink bits for you ungrateful little twerps.
The pinched little faces find this notion difficult to absorb. They stare back blankly at the British Empire. A SIREN SOUNDS an air raid warning.
Books away! Scramble!
They grab their gasmasks and run from the class, cheering

The children file in mostly, laughing and chatting. There are clattering duckboards on the ground affording cover from an inch or two of water. Along each side of the shelters are narrow benches. Gasmasks on!

Slowly... in... out...don't panic... in... out...
There is a HISSING SOUND as they inhale, then a RASPING comic RASPBERRY as the air is pushed out of the sides of the rubber masks.
In... out... These masks are given to us to filter away abominations of the enemy.
He marches up and down in the narrow gap between the scab knees of children.
Now, nine times table. One times nine is nine...

The  children's muffled voices chant the multiplication table rubbery GURGLING SOUNDS merge from the gasmasks. Hidden behind his mask, BILL finally gives was to angry tears. He sticks out his tongue as the HEADMASTER passes by.
Two times nine is eighteen...
(And so on)

They run to the back fence. GRACE and her three children are glimpsed in their seats, watching. BILL is totally engrossed, enthralled. Out of habit, he simulates the engine noise of the planes and th clutter of cannon fire. They shuffle up the aisle, dragging their feet, watching over their shoulders as they go.
Can't we just see the end?
They've got the real thing outside.
It's not the same.

A number of PEOPLE have come out of their suburban garden and look up at the pale-blue-winter sky. GRACE, SUE and BILL are among them. One of the GERMAN PLANES is HIT as the PILOT leaps from h burning plane and a PARACHUTE blossoms and checks his fal GRACE draws the children back into the corner of the hous as the PLANE CRASHES. They creep out again. The dog fight continues but the German planes have lost formation and dispersed. The battle has become straggly and is rapidly disappearing from view. Meanwhile, the PILOT'S PARACHUTE drifts ever CLOSER as he descends, causing great excitement.
NEIGHBOURS run in the direction of the FALLING AIRMAN. So WOMEN carry garden forks and others pick up rocks on the way. GRACE and the children hurry back into the house.
They go out through the back gate to join an excited thro of NEIGHBOURS.

The PILOT drifts on to the wasteland where the barrage balloon bravely flies. People rush in from all sides, as makes an elegant landing and gathers his parachute. A cro of women, children and OLD MEN encircle him. He looks no more than twenty-years old. The crowd watches every move makes. They edge back as he reaches into his pocket. But is only a silk handkerchief that he pulls out. He wipes h hands, puts it away. He moves to an empty oil drum and si on it. He crosses his legs and carefully lights a cigarette. His affects the greatest nonchalance as he smokes. A little way off a huge hoarding gives the impression of the houses that were to be built on this site, an idyll of suburban bliss. The PILOT looks at the idealized family group on the poster and then at GRACE an her children. He smiles ironically.
England is so beautiful, and he had to land here of all places.

Finally, a rather aged POLICE CONSTABLE arrives on the scene. The onlookers thrust him forward. He advances a fe paces, the stops. Hesitating, quite at a loss. He looks a the PILOT then back to the crowd. They egg him on. Resolutely, the CONSTABLE pulls out his truncheon and ste forward.
Now then. Now then.

The German PILOT gets languidly to his feet. The POLICEMA Retreats a pace. A TITTER or two ripples through the crow Encouragingly, the PILOT half raises his hands in the 'stick-em-up' position, the cigarette held delicately between the pale fingers. It is a taunting but oddly gent gesture. The CONSTABLE takes him by the arm and leads him off. The crowd opens up to let them pass. As he does, DAW catches his eye and he winks at her. She gives him a flirtatious smile. GRACE is horrified. She seizes DAWN an forces her face against her own breast, hiding her gaze from the lewdness of the enemy.

DAWN is bent over, looking between her legs at BILL as he tries to draw a stocking seam up the back of her calf. He must continuously lick the brown crayon. She holds a hand mirror in such a way that she can see the progress of his work.
It's crooked. Rub that bit out and do it again.
She cuff's him and he resumes. He stops halfway up her thigh.
Well, keep going. Don't stop now.
He goes higher, then hesitates again.
Nobody is going to see this far up.
She leers at him.
Don't be so sure.
He blushes. She stands up and pirouettes, her flared skir swings out, exposing her knickers.
When I jitterbug.
DAWN, swinging as she jitterbugs with a young CANADIAN SOLDIER, BRUCE. They are good. He hoists her over his shoulder. They whirl and swirl. The music changes to a sl waltz.
It was great for me, how was it for you.
A bit too quick.
Well. Now we can do it slow. Are those some kind of stockings you're wearing?
They might be.
I mean, no suspenders. They just kinda' disappear up your ass.
She slaps his face. He Holds up his hands in mock horror and backs away.
Quit it. Help me someone. The girl's beating on me.

Jeers and laughter from fellow CANADIANS on the dance floor. DAWN turns and walks off, head in the air, but not forgetting to wriggle her bottom as she goes. BRUCE grins admiringly and stalks after her on tiptoe. His pals love it.

A SPITFIRE is attacked by a GERMAN PLANE. The pilot twist and turns away, trying to escape. The pilot is BILL! His eyes bulge with fear as the enemy bullets rip into his fuselage. The rat-a-tat of the gunfire wakes him up.

BILL opens his eyes, and they alight upon his MODEL SPITFIRE suspended on a thread over his bed. The cannon fire gradually resolves into a TAPPING on the WINDOW. Blearily he gets up and unlatches it. A Dishevelled DAWN climbs through, threading her way between the model airplanes hanging from the ceiling and stepping down over the table on which BILL has his shrapnel collection sprea
(whispering) Mind that shrapnel
DAWN thrusts a brass regimental hat badge in BILL'S face.
(whispering) I'm starting my own collection.
(impressed) It's Canadian. Where'd you get it?
She pockets it and creeps out of the door, smiling smugly
DAWN pulls back the covers and slides into bed, fully dressed. She is asleep as her head hits the pillow. A distant SIREN starts-up,warning of an air-raid.

GRACE is instantly alert as the SIRENS call to one anothe coming CLOSER. She throws on her dressing-gown, pulls on her fur-lined boots, picks up the ever-packed bag at her bedside and hurries out of the door.
GRACE shakes BILL and SUE awake.
Bill, Sue. Air-raid!
They tumble out of bed and into their dressing-gowns like automata.
GRACE enters, shakes DAWN who does not respond. GRACE pul back the covers and is surprised to see DAWN fully dresse wearing make-up and with slightly crooked seams down the back of her legs.
Dawn, what have you been up to?
DAWN murmurs her protest. GRACE pulls her out of bed, but DAWN crawls back in.
I'm not going to that shelter. I'd sooner die.

BOMBS are already falling. GRACE switches on a light and hurries down the stairs leading her two children through the familiar routine. She calls back. BILL bumps down the stairs, on his bottom, half asleep.
Dawn! Come down here!
Shew starts back up the stairs, but is halted by a BOMB dropping close by. She runs down again, scoops up the two little ones and heads from the living room.

As they approach the French windows, another BOMB EXPLODE very close by. Before its sound is heard, there is a tremendous BLAST, which rips off the blackout curtains and sends them floating into the room. The WINDOWS are TORN OUT and most of the fragmented glass hangs limply from the brown paper that criss-crosses the panes for just this eventuality. Every loose object is hurled inwards. The room light flickers on and off and shell-bursts illuminate the room from without. GRACE and the children are thrown back against the wall, but before they hit it the process is reversed and the blast is sucked out again. They are pull back towards the windows together with the glass and loos fragments of the room. This all happens slowly as though the room is filled with water and the windows were a reversible sluice gate. SUE'S long blonde-hair is first blown, then sucked across her face. Then comes the SOUND the EXPLOSION itself, Which seems to have the effect od draining water from the room. The People and the bric-a brac all drop to the floor, dead weights once more. Please, God. Take me, but spare them.
She carries SUE and drags BILL through the shattered Fren windows, out into the garden and towards the Anderson shelter.

Two more BOMBS EXPLODE, further way, but still close enou for the blast to force them off balance. They stumble and fall, covering their ears against the pressure. They tumb into the SHELTER, stepping into several inches of water. The ack-ack keeps up the barrage, and the EXPLODING SHELL intermittently LIGHT UP the SKY. GRACE, mumbling Dawn's name, clambers out of the shelter to fetch her. GRACE sees DAWN coming down the garden. She looks dazed a she staggers quite slowly with one arm wound around her head. As she gets closer, GRACE sees that her eyes are glazed and she is MOANING. GRACE leads her into the SHELT and covers her with a blanket. SUE is fast asleep already in spite of everything. DAWN looks at her mother accusingly.
You don't care if I die. How could you leave me there? Even if you don't love me?
DAWN desperately wants her mother to take her in her arms but GRACE sits stiffly upright, unyielding.
Tell me the truth. You had to get married, didn't you? Because of me.
The ideas you get in your head.
That's why you never liked me. I'm different from you. Well, everything's different now, so it doesn't matter. So there.

Finally DAWN bends forward and puts her head on her mother's lap and cries, at first softly, the more bitterl GRACE holds her and rocks her at last. BILL watches this, perplexed, as perhaps he always will be, by the complex emotional interplay that passes between women.

GRACE and DAWN are cleaning up the debris. Some plaster h fallen and there is a pall of dust. They are singing merrily, glad to be alive, to have survived the night. Outside the front window, BILL and SUE can be seen, havin ventured out, eager to explore the damage done to Rosehil Avenue.

Two of them are working a stirrup pump as they extinguish a small fire in a corner of a room. So children come up to BILL and SUE. They are flushed and excited, bursting with news. One buy, ROGER, blurts it ou
Pauline's mum got killed.
No, she didn't.
Yes, she did, didn't she?
He appeals to his companions, particularly to a GIRL, JAN a little older than the others.
Yes, she did. Killed stone dead.
You can ask her. Ask Pauline.

He points over at the ruined house, and sure enough there is PAULINE, a girl of twelve. From time to time, a silicosis NEIGHBOUR goes over to her, offering help, but PAULINE shakes her head and looks away. She just's stands there as though her mother has told her to wait on that spot and not to talk to any strangers until she got back. The children drift across towards her and stop a few feet away. They stare intently, studying her face.
Isn't that right? You're mum got killed last night?
PAULINE nods affirmatively. A BOY throws a miniature parachute into the air. It opens up and drops neatly at PAULINE'S feet.
There you are. I told you.

He jabs BILL in the ribs, finding a physical vent for his excitement. BILL lashes back at him with a violent anger that scares and quells the other boy. The group falls silent. PAULINE steals glances at them out of the corner of her eye. She is not a popular girl, careful and self-consciou and she cannot help enjoying this situation. She flushes.
Do you feel rotten, Pauline?

PAULINE shakes her head. The children move away from her and start to fool around, scrapping and laughing, but whe they get back within a certain distance of PAULINE, they grow quiet and move away again. BILL nudges SUE.
Go and ask her if she wants to play.
Ask her yourself.
You do it. You're a girl.
SUE edges slowly towards her, not without nervous glances back at her brother.
Pauline.
PAULINE does not deign to answer the little girl.
Pauline. Do you want some shrapnel?
She has fragments in her hand. She offers then to PAULINE It is possibly part of the bomb that killed her mother. PAULINE shakes her head.
Do you want to play?
PAULINE shakes her head again. SUE goes back to BILL who has been watching carefully at a distance. After a moment they turn back and walk home. ROGER sees another newcomer approaching. He calls out.
Hey, Terry. Pauline's mum got killed last night.
She never.
She did too.

BILL and SUE enter, bursting with their news. GRACE'S sister, HOPE, has come to help and so have MOLLY and MAC, and a Neighbour, MRS. EVANS, on whom DAWN wished a bomb. GRACE'S arm is bandaged, MAC is scoring panes of glass wi a diamond cutter. He has a dollop of putty. BILL is immediately distracted and cannot resist kneading the putty. DAWN brings in a tray of tea. They are all in high spirits, almost festive. SUE tugs at her mother's skirt.
Pauline's mummy got deaded.
GRACE'S attention is elsewhere. She does not hear.
You're lucky up here. The East End's been burning for three nights. Incendiaries.
DAWN hands the neighbour her tea.
Still not been hit, Mrs. Evans?
Touch wood.
You had a near-miss the other might.
I hear they're dropping diseased rats on bomb sites.
BILL found this tiny little parachute. So that's what it was for.
They all slurp their tea and talk at once. HOPE is dustin the piano.
Is the piano all right, Grace? It was knocked clean over.
GRACE goes over to it and opens the lid, runs her fingers over the keys.
It seems to have survived.
Play something, Grace.
We never used to sing much before the war, did we? Not in daytime anyway.
DAWN starts to sing 'Mareseatoats and Doeseaboats and Littleambseativy' and GRACE picks it up on the piano. DAW dances around the room. There is something wild and abandoned about her.
Dawn's come on fast.
That's the war for you. Quick, quick, quick.
Didn't I see you with a soldier, Dawn?
It is just a teasing guess. She roars with laughter.
I'm just doing my bit for the war effort.
GRACE stops playing.
I won't have this vulgar talk in my house.
It's only a joke, Mummy. I'm fifteen. I'm still at school. I want to be a nun when I grow up.
MAC goes over to GRACE. He picks up some sheet music from pile scattered on the floor. He selects a piece and props it on the music stand.
Try and few bars of old Fred, Grace.

GRACE is softened by his tone. Their eyes meet for a moment. She turns the stool back to the keyboard and play Chopin, particularly poignant since the fall of Warsaw. They listen with teary eyes. 'Mareseatoats and Doeseaboat and Chopin. It is the spirit of the Blitz.
(whispering to Bill) Tell them about Pauline's mum.
Not now. They wouldn't believe me.
The Chopin continues over a scenes of bomb-ruined London, desolate and devastated.

A surreal landscape: a flight of stairs leading nowhere, exposed bathroom; a house entirely destroyed but for one fragment of wall jutting up, and on it still hangs a picture. What are you doing here? This is our territory
Looking for shrapnel.
What you got?
Two of them grab BILL and wrench his fist open, extractin a piece of metal.
Look, a detonator.
The others gather round, scrapping and shoving for a bett look, BILL'S arms are twisted behind his back and his eye are covered with a very dirty handkerchief. They take him to a ruined house.
The room has a brazier, table and chairs. They remove the blindfold and he sees a wondrous sight, a collection of bullets, shells and bomb fragments. ROGER slaps the shell proudly.
Unexploded.
You were spying.
I never was.
Yes, you was. Make him talk.
They twist his arm. Several of the boys are smoking. One takes a .303 Bullet and tightens in into an old vice fixe to the table. BILL is fighting back the tears. ROGER lean over BILL.
I know a secret.
What's that?
The Germans are dropping men on bomb sites.
Who told you that?
They loosen their grip on his arm.

They're not.
BILL has captured their attention. They release him.
If you find them hiding, they cut your throat. They have to, or they'd get found out.
The boys begin to get nervous, glancing about them. The B on the vice aims a nail at the top of the bullet, brandishing a hammer in the other hand.
I wish one would come through the door now.
He hammers the nail and the bullet EXPLODES, embedding itself in the door. They jump out of their skins.
You want to join our gang?
I don't mind.
Do you know any swear words?
Yes.
Say them.
BILL is stubbornly silent.
Well go on then. You can't join if you can't answer.
I only know one.
They laugh derisively.
Well say that one then.
BILL cannot get himself to say it, try as he will. They groan and jeer. BILL forces it out, the one that he heard on the bomb site.
Fuck!
They fall respectfully silent, exchange covert looks.
That word is special. That word is only for something really important. Now, repeat after me... Bugger off.
Bugger off.
Sod.
Sod.
Bloody.
Bloody.
Now put them together. Bugger off, you bloody sod.
Bugger off, you bloody sod.
OK. You're in.
He gets up, leading them out of the room.
Let's smash things up.

They go into a newly bombed house and, armed with stout sticks and iron bars, indulge in an orgy of destruction. ROGER has an air-gun and specializes in picking of light bulbs. BILL is tentative at first, but the violence is infectious. Pent-up aggression bursts and his is wilder a worse than the others.
ROGER leads the way, clambering over a damaged wall and dropping into an enclosed yard. The others tumble after h and ROGER raises a warning arm and addresses the gang solemnly.
This is top secret.
He points to a corner where dozens of sign-posts, uproote from crossroads, have been piled against each other, thei arms spread out forlonly announcing the names of towns an their distances.
They pulled them up from all the crossroads, so when the Germans land they'll lose their way.
Won't they have maps?
They'll have to go to a shop to buy a map, stupid. Then they'll give zemselves avay viz ze vay zay tork.
One BOY starts to goose-step and sing.
(singing) Ven der Fuhrer says Vis iss der master race, Ve vart, vart, vart, Right in der Fuhrer's face.

DAWN, watched by BILL, tiptoes down the stairs. She opens the front door as silently as possible. Vera Lynn dispens sexy sentimentality on the wireless ('Sincerely Yours'). GRACE appears. DAWN is caught in the act.
And where do you think you're going?
Out.
You go to bed this minute and take off that lipstick.
No, I won't.
GRACE files at her, enraged, and slaps her head and face.
You wouldn't dare defy me if your father was here.
DAWN covers her head with her arms until GRACE stops, exhausted.
If you've finished, I'm going.

She steps out of the door. GRACE grabs her, tearing her blouse, and swings her back inside. They wrestle wildly, both whimpering and moaning. BILL watches from above as t fight imperceptibly transforms and mother and daughter ar finally hugging each other and crying.
I want him. I want him so much. I'll kill myself if I can't have him.
There, there, my baby.
GRACE lets go and turns towards the living room where Ver Lynn wails a lament.
Go if you want. What does it matter? We might be all dead tomorrow.
DAWN'S make-up is smudged, her clothes torn.
I can't go like this.
GRACE turns back and takes DAWN'S hand.
You better bring him home, if you really love him. Don't kill love. You'll regret it for the rest of your life.
Who said anything about love?

The gang's H.Q. is even further improved. They have put i some expensive furniture. They have a wireless and a cocktail bar that opens to rev a nest of mirrors reflecting the bottles within. They laugh bawdily and she turns up her nose. One of the starts to wrestle with her. She starts to struggle. They back her arms and try and kiss her. Her breasts push up against her blouse like little apples. ROGER whispers something in her ear. She protests.
Go on, Pauline. Be a sport.
No, I won't. There's too many of you.
One at a time.
No, I won't.
I'll give you something.
He gets a box, opens it and shows it her. It is full of looted jewelry, brooches, cheap bracelets. PAULINE is delighted. She pokes around and chooses a necklace, puts on.

They form a n orderly queue and PAULINE pulls up her skir She holds her knickers open by the elastic so that it is possible to look inside. The boys file past, each peering inside her knickers for a second or two.
I seen better.
BILL is on the end. As his turn approaches, his face is t with apprehension.
It won't bite you.
They all laugh at his expense. Hi swings punches, flying all directions and they hits back. One or two land. They the recipients and they hit back. ROGER calls a halt.

The gang loot and pillage, smashing as they go. Behind a piece of broken wall, BILL discovers a soldier and a girl clasped together, the girl is pressed against a door. BIL moves closer. The soldier fumbles with her clothing, but is so wild with passion that his efforts are impeded. (shouting) Fuck!

Hearing the sacred cry, the gang come running. They see B hurling stones and quickly join in. BRUCE protests angril and throws a couple of rocks himself, but he is overwhelm He protects DAWN from the onslaught and they flee.
