Wasn't that your sister, Rohan?
BILL shakes his head, denying her.

GRACE is cutting down a coat for SUE; BILL is reading a comic, the Dandy; DAWN is darning stockings. The doorbell SOUNDS and DAWN catapults from her chair to greet the visitor. She returns with BRUCE, now evidently a welcome regular guest. BILL throws friendly punches, one wild one catches him in crotch. He takes it bravely. He distributes largesse, a t of corned beef and a packet of tea for GRACE, chewing gum SUE, a model barrage balloon for BILL and a pair of nylon for DAWN.
You need suspenders for this kind.
She laughs, then holds the stockings against her skin in transport of sexual delight.
I'm going to cross my legs and make that rustling noise.
Finally and dramatically, BRUCE pulls out a package in a brown-paper bag. He gives it to GRACE. She opens it. It i piece of beef steak. GRACE is overcome.
Steak! I can't remember the last time...
crooning ironically
'The last time I saw sirloin...' GRACE holds the raw meat in her two hands and impulsively kisses it.
Take it away. I know your husband's been away a long time, but....
Don't be so cheeky, Bruce.
He holds up his hands in supplication.
Sorry, sorry. Too long in the barrack room.

Itma has just ended and a programme has started up about evacuation of Dunkirk. Its tone is quasi-religious - patriotic as it tells of the armada of little boats heroically snatching the remnants of the British Army out the jaws of the Nazis. Churchill's voice booms out of the wireless.
If the British Empire lasts for a thousand years, men will say, this was their finest hour.
BRUCE has been horsing around with BILL, and all the time DAWN devours him with her eyes.
Oh, do let's listen to this. I never tire of listening to it. I gives me goose pimples.
You haven't been taking your orange juice.

The insolent sally gives DAWN the excuse to jump on him a force him on to the sofa and into a respectful silence. Stirring music punctuates the dramatic narration, which celebrates the bravery of the soldiers fighting their las ditch stand. BRUCE giggles.

Don't sound the Dunkirk I was at. I saw no fighting. We did a lot of running backwards, though. Then we got to the beach and we couldn't run no more. And Jerry just sat there and let us alone. If he'd come after us, boy

shakes his head and laughs as though it would have been t funniest moment of the war. We were beat so bad, discipline was all to Hell. We told soldiers to jump in the briny. There was no grub but we b into the wine stores, and everybody got smashed. When the boats came, a lot of guys threw away their gear and fille their kitbags with loot. One buddy of mine burst into a jeweler's, his backpack was full of gold and silver. We h to wade out to the boats and he was so heavy he couldn't himself up. He slipped and sank like a stone. He laughs again. The broadcast comes to its moving climax
How can you say such things? Can't you hear what happened?
I was there.
God laid his hand upon the waters and they were still. The armada of little boats brought their precious cargo into safe havens. They lived to fight another day.
He who turns and runs away lives to fight another day.
The inspiring, patriotic music, Elgar, wells up.
I don't care what you say. It filled our hearts that day. The little people stood up for once against the tyrant. Stood up and said no!
BRUCE impressed, despite himself. DAWN is quite affected by her mother's deep feeling.
That's how we put up with the bombing and the rationing, because of Dunkirk. Because of the spirit of Dunkirk, and because of that we shall never give in, never.
The Elgar continues into:

A shot of troops being ferried from Dunkirk beaches by th little boats. An open fishing boat is packed with soldier mostly standing, while two men row. The soldiers begin to sway and 'la-la' to the Elgar soundtrack. They are seriou and sombre, except for one, BRUCE, who is grinning.
BILL in bed, smiling and in his sleep.
Back to BRUCE singing and smiling.

CLIVE, leather helmet and goggles iced up, rides to the R House on a Norton motorbike. The street is snow-covered a the road is covered in brown slush. BILL and SUE run out greet him. He dismounts painfully, his huge army greatcoa also rimmed with frost. His face is so stiff with cold th he cannot crack a smile and presents an intimidating figu to the children, who draw up  short. When he speaks, he c hardly form words. He staggers alarmingly from the stiffn as he walks, and cramp in one leg makes him hop up and do
On the bike for five hours. Only got a thirty-six hour pass.
He holds out his arms. They cower back, then turn on thei heels and scurry into the house,  calling their mother.

CLIVE has changed into civvies and is soaking his feet in bowl of hot water. Tea has been laid and the family assembled. They watch CLIVE warily. They have learned to without him and his reappearance has upset the new ballan
Hand me my backpack, Bill.
BILL hands it to him and CLIVE proudly pulls out an un labelled can and plants it firmly on the centre of tea ta
And what's that?
Jam.
BILL and SUE jump for joy.
(chanting) Jam! Jam! Jam!
Jam? What kind of jam? It's not like any jam I know.
German jam. It's German jam.
The table falls deathly silent. They stare at the can as though it was a time bomb.
It's all right. It came from a German chip. It got sunk, and this stuff washed ashore, crates of it. Jam. Our fellows found it on the beach, by the rifle range.
GRACE picks it up gingerly, turns it, searches the blank silver-grey metal for a sign, a clue, a portent.
We don't know anything about it
Well, it's off ration. We know that.
How do we know they didn't plant it there? They know we're mad on jam. They could poison half the country.
CLIVE surveys the suspicious hostile faces. Angrily, he seizes the can and jabs it clumsily with the paper opener
Come away, children. I don't want you to stand too close while he's opening it.
They retreat to the corner of the room. CLIVE has it open and bends back the top to reveal a deep-red jam. GRACE ventures forward and peers at it.
Well?
It looks....foreign.
Jam is jam! It's just jam!
Well, I'm not having any. Even if it's not poisoned. I don't think it's right. It's not patriotic.
You don't like jam. You hate jam. You never eat jam.
That's not the point.
There is an impasse. They stare at it gloomily. CLIVE wav grandly at the jam.
Taste it. Why don't you taste it?
You taste it.

The eyes turn on CLIVE. The situation forces their resent for one who has not shared in their hardships, who abando them, in fact. The jam has become a test. He looks into t faces of his family. Resolutely, he takes up a teaspoon, picks up the can and begins to eat. Grimly and steadily h ladles the jam to his mouth. They watch him carefully for signs of pain. Before their doubts are dispelled, he has consumed a third of the can. BILL is the first to crack.
Give us some, Dad.

CLIVE stops eating, puts the can back on the table and th all dig in. The tension is dispelled. SUE climbs on CLIVE lap and he feeds her himself. They laugh and chatter and stuff bread and jam in their mouths.
You mean they let you go through the officer training course and then said you were too old for a commission?
That's it.
Why didn't they say that before you started?
I wasn't too old when I started the course. I was too old when it finished.
What are you going to be then?
A clerk. I'm doing a typing course. I'll be typing for England.
GRACE goes to him, puts an arm around him.
Poor Clive. You wanted it so much.
He looks up at her, beaten, uncomprehending. She kisses h
You're such a baby.
The DOORBELL SOUNDS. DAWN scoots out to answer it.
It's lovely jam. It's nearly as nice as English jam.
CLIVE grins, quickly recovered from his bad moment.
You know what I always say? Jam is jam, the world over.
DAWN reappears with BRUCE. CLIVE darts a querying look at GRACE. He winces at the sight of his little girl looking adorningly at a Canadian soldier.
Bruce, this is my father. Dad, this is Corporal Bruce Carey.
CLIVE laughs awkwardly, outranked.
Bruce, look! Dad got some German jam.
We thought it was poison.
They laugh. BRUCE looks at it with mock suspicion, then tastes it with his fingertip. His eyes bulge and he clutc his throat.
The poison was at the bottom.
He falls to the ground in the most agonized convulsions. children scream with laughter and jump on top of him.

The kitchen door is open, admitting thin winter sunlight. GRACE works within. Outside, CLIVE is cleaning his kit, helped by BILL. Belt and gaiters are balanced and laid ou dry. CLIVE is sitting on the steps, putting dubbin on his boots,  BILL polishing his father's hat badge, totally absorbed in its beauty. GRACE appears, outs a hand on CLI shoulder, closes her eyes, let's the sun caress her face.
When do you think you'll get leave again?
Not till Christmas, I don't suppose.
SUE appears and sprawls herself across her father's lap.
I'm glad you didn't send them to your aunt.
I've had a letter from her. They've moved house.
Where to?
She smiles, eyes still closed.
Woolamaloo.
CLIVE splutters with amusement.
Not Woolamaloo?
BILL looks up, grinning.
Woolamaloo? We would have lived in Woolamaloo?
CLIVE starts to sing the old music-hall song.
(singing) W-O-O-L-A-M-A-L-O-O, oo. Upon my word, it's true. It's the way to spell Woolamaloo.
They join in, in a ragged way, knowing it well.
(singing) I bet you a dollar, There isn't a scholar, To spell it right first go, O, W-O-O-L-A-M-A-L-O-O, Loo-O
DAWN comes through the kitchen with MAC and MOLLY, who fi the Rohans in good spirits. There are arm greetings all round.
BILL is giving his father and MAC a tour of the bomb dama He picks his way expertly through the rubble, and they clamber after him.

What kind of war is this Mac? Up there in Cumberland, we never see an air-raid. The worst problem I have is getting a new typewriter ribbon. When I rode in against the Turks, I knew what it was about.
Did you? You thought you did. We've been gypsed, all our lives. Look at your street.
They pause, looking out of a shattered window on the stre It is a monotonous row of semi-detached houses, lying bet other identical rows, now pocked with bomb damage, drab a dreary.
What about it?
Rosehill Avenue. No roses. No hill. And it's certainly not an avenue.
Why not?
You need trees for an avenue.
There was talk of planting some when we first came.
Propaganda. We've been had.
They fall silent, watching BILL as he greets some other b
How's your war, Mac?
Never done better. On the fiddle. Like everyone else.
Except the servicemen.
Naturally.
I don't understand. Is there any point to it?
There is all right. This Hitter fellow. We've got to winkle him out. And get shot of some of our lot at the same time.
They watch BILL rooting about in the rubble.

Look at how wild the boy's got. As for Dawn. Sixteen, going around with a soldier. (shakes his head) Keep and eye on them for me, Mac, there's a pal. I've made a mess of it all. (his voices cracks. A sob wells up.) I've been such a bloody fool.
BILL has come up behind them and watches covertly. MAC cl CLIVE in his arms.
You always were, Clive. Steady the Buffs.
Bugger the Buffs.

Cries and shouts come from the street. BILL swings across crater on a dangling electric cable and scrambles into th road. There is panic and pandemonium. The local barrage balloon's fins have punctured and it has lost stability. is careering wildly like a kite out of control. CLIVE and clamber into the street as the balloon skims across the s its steel cable shearing a chimney stack which tumbles do onto the front garden sending people scattering in all directions. BILL runs up,  mad with excitement, as SUE an DAWN come out of the house with GRACE and MOLLY and look CLIVE sprints across to them.
Take cover! We're being attacked by our own balloons!
They take no notice of his entreaty, curiosity getting th better of them.
It's having a nervous breakdown.
She giggles. The balloon bumps on the rooftop then shoots into the sky again. GRACE starts to laugh.
It's so wonderful.
CLIVE earnestly dashes back and forth, wanting to do something, but completely unable to decide what.
Don't panic! (goes over to Mac) Keep your head!
I will if you will!
The balloon does a fat little waltz in the sky. CLIVE suddenly explodes with laughter. DAWN has SUE in her arms
He just got fed up with all the other boring old barrage balloons and decided it was time to have some fun.

Two ARP MEN run down the street, urging people to go insi The family retreat grudgingly towards their house, but ho in the front garden watching and laughing. Six HOME GUARD march into Rosehill Avenue at the double. The balloon has risen into the sky and the people are drawn out again int the street, looking up. The HOME GUARDS come to a halt an raise their rifles.
Boo! Leave it alone!
The balloon suddenly plunges down towards the street, scattering the HOME GUARDS. Women SCREAM and everyone das for cover again. BILL laughs derisively.
They're scared of old fatty.

The GUARDS form up again and fire at the balloon. It burs into flames. The shreds of burning cloth, followed by the spiralling cable, plunges into the street. There are crie regret and the family and others step forward to inspect smouldering remains with the same sadness that is felt at end of a firework display.
Why did they have to go and do that?

A make-do-and-mend session, where clothes are exchanged, repaired, altered and cut down. It is swarming with women children. MOLLY and GRACE rummage among the racks of clothing. SUE and BILL, bored and resigned, are obliged t try on items of used clothing.
God, how I hate all this scrimping and squalor.
I don't mind it. It was harder before the war. Trying to keep up appearances. Now it's patriotic to be poor.
In the absence of men, women are everywhere stripping dow their underwear to try on the clothes. BILL tries not to watch, acutely embarrassed.
I don't know how you cope, Grace. Three kids, army pay. On your own.
You know something, Molly? I like it on my own. I never got used to sharing a bed, not really.
MOLLY pulls of her dress and suddenly, inches from BILL'S face, are those mysterious few inches of white suspendere leg between the stocking-tops and the camiknickers.

I love a man in bed, the smell of him, the hairiness rubbing against you, the weight of him. And when they do it to you in the middle of the night and you don't know if you're dreaming or it's really happening to you. That's the best. No guilty feelings. Not that I should have any, wide awake.
MOLLY pulls on a flowered silk dress that clings to her figure. She smooths it out.
Molly!
Well! I'm not talking about Mac. He hasn't toughed me for ages. And not often ever. My life started when Mac went on nights.
She dissolves in a fit of giggles. GRACE helps SUE with a sensible navy-blue coat. It is heavy and dull. SUE doesn' like it. Her face creases and tears well up.
You're having me on, Molly.
Am I? Maybe I am.
You've been drinking. Your tipsy.
Tipsy, topsy, turvy.

BILL and SUE each have a torch, which serve as a searchli BILL smokes a woodbine and he blows the smoke around the suspended model aircraft. Spitfires, Hurricanes, Messerschmitts, Heinkels are picke out in turn. As they appear,BILL simulates their engine noise. With considerable dexterity, he uses his free hand fire his ack-ack guns, and papier-mache pellets, pre-soak in ink, fly through the air. BILL animates a distressed p plummeting to earth. His triumph is interrupted by a TAP the window. Expertly he dogs his Woodbine then goes to th window. He opens it and DAWN steps through. He is about t close it after her when BRUCE'S face appears. BILL lets f an ink pellet catching BRUCE square on the forehead. DAWN holds up a threatening hand and the children shrink back BRUCE clambers in. The two of them tiptoe into the next bedroom, DAWN throwing a warning glance over her shoulder

BILL and SUE share the keyhole, which affords a partial v of Dawn's bed. Complicated combinations of limbs cross th field of view, offering a tantalizing version of events within. The children give up and return to their room, whispering.
I suppose they're still learning, that's why they keep moving about.
It's easy. I've done it.
Who with?
Pauline.
Liar. Mummy keep still and Daddy moves on top of her. That's what they do when they know how.
BRUCE turns on his back with a deep sigh of satisfaction.
(whispering) Boy, that was some air-raid.
Air-raid?
Didn't you feel the house rock? You must have seen all those shell bursts.
She sticks the pillow in her mouth to stop laughing. BRUC turns and whispers in her ear.
Let's get married. We'll live in Montreal. I'll teach you French. Je t'aime, mon petit chou.
Even when he's serious, his manner is teasing.
Don't get smoochy. You'll spoil it.
She is genuinely irritated.

A scene from a forties romantic movie. The couple on the screen are deeply in love, but he must go off to the war. Their parting is bitter-sweet, prolonged and accompanied symphony orchestra playing its heart out.

MAC sits between MOLLY and GRACE. He looks from one to th other. They are both weeping, lost in the movie, and oblivious of him. SUE sleeps, lyin across her mother's lap. BILL squirms with embarrassment the screen lovers kiss. He turns his face away. When he l back, he is disgusted to see that they are still at it.

BILL leans over to the balustrade of the pillar portico looking out on to Trafalgar Square. The strains of  a passionate piano recital reverberate from inside the Gall Soldiers and their girls, hand in hand, listen enraptured
Barrage balloons hang over Admiralty Arch and garland Nel astride his column.
BILL threads his way through the crowd, past signs announ Dame Myra Hess's lunchtime concerts (SOLD OUT) and into t marbled hall.

BILL slides back into his seat next to GRACE as DAME Myra concludes the WARSAW Concerto. The audience rises to its feet, applauding, GRACE, he eyes shining, is among them. watches her pleasure with pleasure. BILL is disturbed by the music, by the eruption of emotio and some wearing blue uniforms demoting the war wounded. clap and clap.
Mac, that was wonderful. I haven't been to a concert since...
...since I used to take you to the Proms?
That's right. Not since then Not since I got married.

Their eyes meet. The audience is drowning in it own appla Everyone is crying, or laughing, or both. GRACE and MAC a them. In the emotional tumult they reveal more than they intend. The audience falls silent. BILL'S gaze drifts to wall where huge paintings by special war artists hang. GR tears her eyes away from MAC. She senses BILL watching he and turns her attention to Dame Myra's fingers flying ove the keys.

The table has been stretched to embrace the Rohan family, including GRACE'S SISTERS. They wear paper hats, have finished their Christmas dinner, and are listening attentively to King George VI stuttering painfully throug his Christmas message.

It is raining. BRUCE hurries along the street, and as he enters the Rohan's front gate, he pauses, pulls an old si stocking over his head and takes two glass eyes from his pocket. They look as though they once belonged to a stuff stag. He pushes them inside the stocking and positions th just under his own eyes so that he can peek over them. He crawls under the bow window.
The King falters to a conclusion.
He was a lot better this year.
MAC and the others mumble agreement.
You said that last year, Dad.
The land and the King are one, my son. If he stutters we falter. He's getting batter, and so are we.
The National Anthem strikes up on the wireless. They all and stand to attention.

BRUCE raises his head and presses his grotesque face to t window. He taps on the glass. He is startled to see the assembled family standing upright and staring back at him without expression. He cavorts and waves his arms, but st gets no response. Sheepishly, he slinks into the porch an pulls off the stocking. The door opens to reveal DAWN.
Dad's furious. It was 'God Save The King'.

He goes inside and she closes the door. He pushes the sta eyes into his own sockets and scrunches up his face to gr them into place. DAWN turns back and he lunges, trying to kiss her. She squeals wit laughter.

A charade is in progress. CLIVE and MAC are got up as prostitutes, wearing their wives'  clothes. GRACE and MOL are dressed as men. There is a lot of salacious flirting an argument breaks out over the price of whores. MOLLY sa the word 'tart' emphatically and BILL jumps out of his se yelling:
Jam tart! Jam tart! I got it! I got it!
The four actors abandon their characterizations and appla young BILL. BRUCE watches in amazement.
Jesus Christ! This is Christmas?
GRACE'S father rises, his glass held aloft.
The for my annual toast. Charge your glasses.

There are groans and mutterings of disapproval. He cuts a impressive figure,white hair, drooping moustache, waistco and watch-chain. His eyes take on a faraway look, sombre serious. His wife, pointedly leaves the room, slamming th door behind her.

To Mary McDonald, Thelma Richardson, Bobo Hinds, Lily Sanderson... (savours each name, smiles, shakes is head, has a special emphasis or tone of voice for every one of them.) ...Little Sarah Whats-it, now there was a spirit. And Marjorie Anderson.
Father, that's enough now
And...and...Henry Chapman's girl, was it Thelma? No, I can see those cornflower eyes...I've lost your name, my sweetness.
Tears come to his eyes. He falters. There are cries of 'shame'. HOPE, GRACE'S sister, jumps to her feet.
Do we have to listen to this nonsense every year? You're drunk, Dadda. Sit down.

...Betty Browning...Betty, let me tell you something. I'm seventy three years old, I've seen half the wonders of the world and I never laid eyes on a finer sight than the curve of Betty Browning's breasts...

raises his glass again My girls Dead you may be, or old and withered. But while live, I will do you honour to the last. Bless all of you. He drinks and slumps down into his chair, overcome with melancholy. Only MOLLY applauds and only DAWN looks sympathetic. BILL taps his grandfather's knee.
It was Sheila, Grandpa.
GRANDFATHER GEORGE looks up  sadly.
What's that?
Henry Chapman's daughter. It was Sheila. I remember her from last year.
So it was. Sheila. This boy will go far.
BILL turns away to DAWN, stifling his giggles.
I made it up!
DAWN and BRUCE kiss goodbye in the porch. She pulls away, sensing something amiss.
What's wrong?
He looks away, unhappy and awkward.
What is it?
We're not supposed to say, but we're being shipped out tomorrow.
Where?
I don't know?
You do, you do. You're just not saying.
I swear I don't know. (offers her a little box) Here's your Christmas present.
She opens it. A diamond ring. She gasps, then trusts it b at him angrily.
You expect me to spend the rest of the war sitting at home staring at a ring? And you'll meet some French girl who can speak your own language. No thank you!
Please yourself.
BRUCE hurls the little box into the next-door bomb site a storms off into the night. DAWN slams the door.
DAWN buries her head in a cushion, crying and wailing. On MAC and MOLLY of the guests remain, and they are playing cards with CLIVE and GRACE. GRACE goes to comfort DAWN.
What is it, pet?
He's being posted. I was terrible to him.
Don't leave it like that. Go after him. Swallow your pride.

CLIVE and DAWN riding pillion, pull up at the Guard House his old Norton. DAWN slides down and hurries to the Guard House. CLIVE props up the bike and follows her. A convoy trucks pulls out of the gate. Soldiers lean out of the ba of the lorries, cheering and whistling when they see DAWN
The SERGEANT of the Guard sits toasting his toes on a cok stove. DAWN addresses CLIVE as he enters.
We've missed them. They've gone. (turns back to the Sergeant) Can't you tell me where? You can see I'm not a spy.
I would if I could, but I can't.
He points to a  wall on which two posters are pinned. One says 'Careless talk costs lives, the other, ' Walls Have Ears'. DAWN is shattered. CLIVE puts his arm about her.
He'll write as soon as he can.
Sure, he will. You'll meet again (sings) don't know where, don't know when. But in the meantime, I am free tomorrow night.
CLIVE leads her out. A sprig of mistletoe hangs over the door. DAWN rips it down and flings it back at the SERGEAN It hits him square in the face.
CLIVE is packed up, ready to go. The family has come to b farewell, all except BILL, who suddenly appears with a triumphant whoop.
I found it! I found it!
He hands the little ring box to DAWN. She opens it and lo at the ring, but does not put it on her finer. CLIVE and GRACE watch tenderly.
You needn't have bothered, Bill.
They watch CLIVE as he rides away. Behind them, the Chris tree can be seen in the window. As they turn to go in, GR looks warily at DAWN.
That letter this morning, was it from Bruce?
DAWN nods.
What did he say?
He said I was right. I shouldn't wait for him. I was better to make a clean break.
I think it's very sensible in the circumstances.
Now he's gone and made me fall in love with him, which I never wanted to do. I told him that.
She runs into the house and up the stairs.

GRACE, MAC, BILL and SUE are finishing a frugal picnic on beach. They are muffled up against the nip of early sprin The sand is criss-crossed with pointed iron spikes and co of barbed wire. Curt signs warn against mines and other hazards. BILL and SUE start to play happily and messily i the sand. In the distance, they hear MUFFLED, deep-throat EXPLOSIONS.
What's that?
Big Berthas, shelling France. Twenty-five-mile range, they have.
Wow!
They send over a few every day, to let them know we're still here. Each shell costs as much as a Ford 8.
Who pays for them?
We will, you will, for the rest of our lives?
BILL gets out a rubber ball, and spins it in is fingers.
Remember this beach, Mac? All those summers. Out two families, together.
Happy days. (watches Bill's efforts with the ball) When you're bigger, Bill, I'll teach you the googly.
BILL smiles a secret smile.
Thanks.
GRACE starts to sing.
(singing) There'll be blue birds over, The white cliffs of Dover...
MAC and the children join in. BILL practices his spin, fi and wrist.
(singing) ...tomorrow. Just you wait and see...
Another CRUMP from Big Bertha.
There goes another Ford 8, Uncle Mac.
The train is unlit to comply with the blackout, the only illumination being as the fire-box door of the loco opene

Moonlight flickers intermittently into the compartment, lending a jerky, monochrome quality to the scene. SUE sle thumb in mouth. BILL dozes in the corner of the compartme GRACE and MAC sit side by side.
(softly) Mac, did you ever find out who Molly went off with?
A Polish pilot. It's like one of those jokes on the wireless.
He stares out of the window, the pale broken light making patterns on his face.
You miss her. I know you do.
He smiles ruefully.
She said, 'I know you love me, Mac, but you've never loved me enough.'
Not loving enough. That is a terrible thing to do to someone. I suppose I did it to Clive. Always held something back.
BILL stirs and fidgets, half hearing, squinting through drooping lids. MAC and GRACE lower their voices further whispering.
It's all better left unsaid, Grace.
You were never apart, you and Clive. He kept asking and asking. And I waited and waited for you to say something. And you never did.
Clive had a job. I didn't. I couldn't.
They fall silent. GRACE smiles ruefully.
He could always make me laugh.
We did the decent thing.
This war's put an end to decent things. I want to close my eyes and jump and give myself for once, hold nothing back.
We can't change what's past. Not even the war can do that.
We did all the proper things, and we lost love. That's sad, Mac.
Their eyes meet and acknowledge what might have been, of happiness accidentally missed.
If I saw this at the pictures, I'd be crying my eyes out, but I can't shed a tear for myself.

In the pale half-light, they seem young and innocent. He takes her hand. They almost kiss. But for children, they would. Finally, MAC turns away and looks out at the dark, heavy shapes of the approaching city.

As GRACE, MAC, BILL and SUE turn into the avenue, they se house burning. It is theirs. When they get closer, they s it is gutted and the roof has collapsed. The firemen have hoses trained on it, but it is too hot to get into the fr door. GRACE'S first thought is for her Daughter.
Dawn! Dawn!
DAWN is with a knot of neighbours, watching the blaze. GR is so relieved to see her that she smiles and becomes qui tranquil.
Thank God you're safe.
The FIRECHIEF approaches her.
Was this your house, madam?
I didn't know there was a raid.
It wasn't a bomb, just afire.
What do you mean, a fire?
It happens in wartime as well, you know.
MAC is shattered. He puts an arm round GRACE. She throws a look, haunted with guilt, and she moves away to console children, who watch the blaze impassively.
I just wished I'd worn my nylons.
GRACE suddenly seized by a dread thought. She runs to the FIRECHIEF.
My ration books are in there.
She makes a wild dash at the house, but MAC and the neighbours restain her. BILL remains next to the FIRECHIE
My shrapnel collection should be all right.
Oh yes, I should think so.

Mac's car drives up to the charred ruins of the house. GR and the children get out. ROGER and his gang are already looting. BILL charges ROGER and punches him in the face. fall and roll in the wet ashes. The bigger boy is so take aback by BILL'S ferocity that he cannot gain an advantage MAC stops GRACE from interfering, understanding the boy's need. PAULINE has appeared and smiles knowingly as she watches. Other children gather. ROGER picks himself up and the gan beats a retreat.
GRACE, MAC, DAWN and SUE join BILL in the house and scrat among the debris to see what can be salvaged.
They ferry bit and pieces to the car. GRACE discovers the charred remnants of a photo album. There are pictures wit burnt fragments and she carries it carefully to the car.
Mac, look! Some of the snaps are saved.

It is open at the picture of the two families at the very beach they visited yesterday. It is burned around the edg only MOLLY and CLIVE are unscathed and they smile happily GRACE and MAC look at it then at each other. It feeds the guilt. The neighbours gather and awkwardly try to express their sympathy. MRS. EVANS arrives with some clothes.
This coat should fit you Grace. And here are some things for Dawn. And a few bits for the kitchen.
Thank you, Evelyne.
BILL is acutely embarrassed. He catches PAULINE'S smirkin look. He fights to hold back the tears, but finally fails
It's only a house. We still have each other.
I don't care about the house, I just hate all these people watching us and being nice.

Carrying GRACE and the three children, MAC's car draws up the towpath facing an island on which is a number of wood bungalows with verandas decorated in fretted scroll work. Neat lawns slope down to the river's edge where varnished punts and skiffs like sleekly tethered. GRANDFATHER GEORG has spotted them and he rear-sculls his dinghy across the water to fetch them.
Coming. Coming. Deliverance is at hand. All will be well.

GRANDMOTHER comes down from the bungalow to the edge of t river and waves encouragingly. BILL is captivated by the river. Moorhens thread through the tendrils of weeping willow. As electric slip launch is moored where they wait strokes its glassy varnish. MAC unloads the boot of the c
Another world, eh Billy? And not twenty miles from Picadilly.
GRACE comes alongside DAWN and waves her mother on the fa bank, only forty yards away. DAWN glances nervously at GR
Are you strong enough for another shock? You're going to be a grandma. (waves across the river at her own Grandmother.) Hello, Grandma.
GRANDFATHER GEORGE  docks his craft expertly and lassoes mooring post. GRACE lets out an hysterical cry.
I don't believe this is happening to me.
It's not. It's happening to me.
responding to GRACE
It's only a house, and a ghastly one at that. They should be burned and bombed and the builder hanged. MAC and GRANDFATHER GEORGE load the family's few possessi on the boat.
What did I do to deserve this?
You married that fool, Clive, that's what. Never mind, you can stay with us.
(to Dawn) How long?
Three and a half months.
As long as that? Well, all right. Why not? It's nearly summer. Let the nippers run wild.
The children have got into the boat. GRACE turns to MAC a kisses him awkwardly.
Bless you, Mac. What would I have done without you?
(ruefully) You might still have a house.
(wistfully) I wish it could all have been different.
Look after yourself, Grace.
He watches them as they cross the river, conscious of the widening between himself and GRACE.
Everything I have left in the world is in this little boat.
BILL studies GRANDFATHER GEORGE's sculling technique.
Can I try?
Put your hand on mine, get the knack of it.
BILL holds the gnarled old hand and moves in unison.
I shall teach you the ways of the river. Another year in that awful suburb and you would be past saving. Look, they're coming this way! The future on the march. I curse you, Volt, Watt and Amp.
Looming over GRANDFATHER GEORGE's bungalow is a newly constructed electric pylon.
BILL wakes, looks at the river.

A grey dawn light touches the mist lying over a glassy ri BILL comes down out of the house and stands at the edge o the water: not a breath of wind, not a soul stirring. He slips out of his grandfather's voluminous pajama pants. Delicately, he lowers himself into the river, careful not crack the perfect smoothness of the water. He slides slow in until only his head is showing. He swims out into the centre of the stream, without disturbing the water. He st takes a breath then submerges, leaving not a ripple, neve trace. The dawn river is once more unobserved, its secret self again.
BILL comes in wet from bathing, to find DAWN half dressed contemplating her slightly swollen nave. They share a sma room in which are two bunk beds.
Have a listen. See if you can hear anything.
With some reluctance, BILL puts an ear to her stomach. Hi cold wet hair gives her a shock. She slaps him.
You're icy cold. A shock like that could give me a miscarriage. (grinning) That's an idea, do it again.
DAWN giggles and it is BILL's turn to be shocked.
Breakfast, all!
DAWN leaves the room while BILL climbs into his clothes.

The room lets out, through open French windows, on to a b garden sown with vegetables for some yards and then givin way to orchard and pasture. The morning sun streams in. GRANDFATHER GEORGE sits at ne end facing the garden. GRAC SUE, GRANDMA and DAWN flank him. GRANDFATHER GEORGE  is n the best in the morning. He glares at BILL as he enters a slips quietly into his seat.
Did they say how long it would take to get new ration books, Grace?
(shouting and emancipating) Up to six weeks, I think.
How are we going to cope?
Nettle soup, like we did in the Great War. Very nourishing. Bill and I will catch fish. The river fowl will be laying eggs soon. We'll hunt, We'll forage. We'll overcome.
What about tea and sugar. Clever Dick?
GRANDFATHER GEORGE holds up a warming hand.
Keep still! Nobody move!
His aspect fills them with dread. His eyes are boring hol in the cabbage patch, outside the French windows, where a is crouching.
(dramatic whisper) Mother!! Fetch my gun.
What's that, dear?

He points urgently at where the gun stands against the wa GRANDMA creeps on tiptoe over to the gun and hands it to resuming her place without making a sound. He raises the shotgun, aiming along the length of the table. The childr are statues, only their eyes darting from him to the rat back. The barrel is inches from their faces. He fires. Th jump. Smoke fills the room, He curses under his breath, a the rat escapes. He puts down the gun and readdresses his boiled egg, as an afterthought, he turns to BILL.
Never let a rat creep up on you.
I think you hit him, Grandpa. He was limping when he ran off.

GRANDFATHER GEORGE gives him a searching look, but BILL i all innocence. DAWN stifles a giggle. GRACE sees what goe and suppresses a smile herself. BILL suddenly coughs and splutters to hid his laughter. DAWN goes red in the face, tears come to her eyes and her shoulders shake. SUE suddenly tinkles with innocent mirth the suppressed laughter bursts out of them all. They roar gasp and shudder and cannot stop. GRANDMA, quiet perplexe smiles, happy to see them all so happy. GRANDFATHER GEORG eyes blazing with anger, glares at them disdainfully, but dam has burst and, fear him as they do, the laughter pour out unabated and their eyes are filled with tears.
GRANDFATHER GEORGE  poles the punt up the river. GRACE,  GRANDMA and SUE lounge in the cushions. BILL stands along the old man, learning the way of it.
Up, two, three. Throw the pole forward, let it slide through your fingers.  Don't push until it hits the bottom.
BILL takes it all in.
Now check that spinner.
BILL crawls along the shiny deck and hauls in a fishing l
No luck, Grandpa.
He lets it out again. A wood-fired steam launch, all poli brass, with an elegant canopy, chugs past them. An elderl couple occupies it, seated in wicker armchairs.
(raises his cap to them) Good day, ma,am. Greetings Edward.
They are beguiled by the smell of the afternoon. GRACE tr her fingers dreamily through in the water. Willows, bulrushes, glides past.

...such nice boys with straw boaters and blazers. All the punts lit up with Chinese lanterns. Like fireflies. And the gramophone going on one of the boats. Always the Charleston, the Charleston, the Charleston. Oh, you girls.
Wasn't it lovely?
GRANDFATHER GEORGE entrusts the pole to BILL. He struggle with the technique, does quite well. The the pole sticks deep mud. He cannot extricate it.
Let it go. Let it go.
But BILL hangs on to the pole and the punt moves on until is stretched between them. Finally, he hops on to the pol and clings to it.
Stay put. Hang on.

He takes a paddle and drives the boat back to where BILL stranded. The pole starts to topple in a small arc. GRANDFATHER GEORGE renews his efforts and BILL is able to step neatly on to the rear decking. The old an eases the from the mud.
Now there's a lesson for life. Never give up the punt for the pole.

Tea is being laid on the lawn by GRANDMA, GRACE and DAWN; GRANDFATHER GEORGE reclines in the faded swing-seat. BILL ferries FAITH, HOPE and CHARITY (his three aunts) to the island in the dingy. He rear-sculls with some difficulty, well enough. GRANDFATHER GEORGE examines his daughters wi binoculars as they 'ooh' and 'aah' greetings on their approach. They disembark and there is much hugging and kissing. They have all brought clothing for the family an dresses and blouses are held up, examined and admired. The daughters clearly disapprove of GRANDFATHER GEORGE an only offer perfunctory kisses, HOPE ignoring him complete SUE is held up and passed from hand to hand as though she were a frock herself. They take it in turns to shout clarification to their mother. They flutter around DAWN, is now showing her pregnancy.
No word from Bruce, my pet?
It was meant well, but it makes DAWN bristle.
All men are beasts, darling.
That's what I like about them.
Dawn! Really!
BILL slides over to his grandfather.

All hens and no cocks. Too many women in the family. They're a different species from us, Bill. Love them, but don't try to understand them. That road leads to ruin. Let's make a nuisance of ourselves.
He mingles among the women, deciding to goad his daughter HOPE.
You look frustrated, Hope. That husband of yours still can't rise to the occasion?
HOPE flares up, but bites her tongue and turns away. GRANDFATHER GEORGE turns to BILL, confidingly.
I won't have the husbands here. All four married duds, including your mother.
He's a menace. He ought to be locked up.
Don't let him get his claws into you Billy, Grace.
GRANDFATHER GEORGE continues his advice to BILL.
They'll tame you if they can, cage you and feed you tidbits. Better retreat to prepared positions.

He leads BILL round to the back garden away  from the riv All the bungalows are built up on piers against flooding. reaches under the house and retrieves an old cricket bat ball. He thrusts the ball at BILL.
Bags I bat first.

He takes guard against the trunk of an old apple tree. BI twists his fingers around the ball and bowls a spinner to GRANDFATHER GEORGE who waits for it to break, then plays back. The next ball breaks the other way and clean bowls GRANDFATHER GEORGE looks back at BILL with astonishment.
That was a googly!
I know.
You're a dark horse, bowling googlies at your age. Toss me up another.
No, you're out, Grandpa. It's my turn.

With ill grace, GRANDFATHER GEORGE surrenders the bat and offers a harmless arthritic delivery which BILL thumps in the gooseberry bushes. GRANDFATHER GEORGE curses and pric his fingers as he tries to retrieves the ball. He looks u irritably at the sounds of laughter from his daughters. H snarls in their direction.
Want to know why they're called Faith, Hope, Grace and Charity?
Why?
Your grandmother. She named them after virtues I lack. That's marriage for you.
He bowls again. BILL hammers it away. GRANDFATHER GEORGE glares at him, trembling with fury.
It's only a game, Grandpa.
GRANDFATHER GEORGE gets himself under control and trots o to find the ball.

BILL and SUE are in the dingy, pushing a stand of reeds. hangs over and bows, hauling the boat along by pulling on reeds. The parting rushes reveal a moorhens nest, neatly suspended above the water on bent-over reeds meshed toget There are some dozen speckled eggs. BILL carefully extrac one of them ad places it in a little basket in the boat, which already contains a number of eggs which he has presumably taken from other nests. Further upstream, BILL steps out of the boat into some shallows. He gropes under the water and hauls up a night fishing li SUE shares his disappointment when there is no catch.
The dingy pulls up at the landing stage. GRANDFATHER GEOR using a stick, limps down the garden to meet them. SUE ha him the basket of eggs.
Where's the fish? No fish, no supper. Be off with you and don't come back empty handed.

He gives the boat a shove with his stick and turns back t the house. SUE looks weepy. BILL mouths some of his repertoire of swear words. From the dormer window, DAWN witnesses their humiliation. She laughs and waves. As GRANDFATHER GEORGE turns back to the house, she ducks out sight.

They row up to the head of the weir. BILL casts a line an fixes the rod to the gunwale, He ties up the boat and sli over the side. He checks a net arrangement he has fixed a the base of the waterfall to snare unwary fish swimming o the weir. It is empty. SUE paddles in the soft weed that grows on the steps of the weir, letting it seep between h toes. BILL kneels and runs his fingers through the same luminous-green weed. They become absorbed in it. BILL low his body into the water and lets himself slide over the w SUE follows suit. Soon they have discovered a glorious ga sliding like eels down the weir and plunging into the poo below. Back and forth they go. In the far distance, an ai raid siren wails, They pay no attention, so caught up are they in their pleasure. SUE checks the fishing line fixed the boat. Nothing.
I'm scared of going back without any fish. I hate Grandpa.
They look up at the SOUND of 'ack-ack' fire. BILL spots a German plane high above them.
Looks like a stray bomber. He's lost his squadron.

Suddenly there is a BLAST OF AIR and a BOOMING EXPLOSION. hundred yards up the river, a great plume of water spurts They drop flat on the steps of the weir. BILL peers cautiously over the rim of the waterfall. SUE seems his astonishment turn to a broad grin. Floating towards the w are dozens of fish stunned by the blast. Joyously, they gather them up and throw them into the boat.
GRACE, dawn and the GRANDPARENTS all look amazed admirati at the boat laden with fish.
This is going too far, young man.
But Grandpa, you said...
I concede I was insistent, but how the Devil...
DAWN looks sharply at the smug faces of her brother and sister.
It looks a bit fishy to me.
Could we salt them, or smoke them, do you think?
They fall to unloading the fish.
It's like feeding of the five thousand. It's a miracle.
Well,lad. So it's miracles now, is it?
They'll stink the place out by morning. Why not invite all your friends to supper, Grandpa.
He looks up darkly from his task.
I have no friends, only relations.

BILL, now wielding the pole with great aplomb, send the p gliding up river. DAWN heavily pregnant and languidly melancholic, lies in the cushions, bare foot dangling in river. DAWN stiffens as the figure of a man in uniform co running along the riverbank. As he catches up with them, is revealed as BRUCE and the uniform of a Canadian soldie He waves and calls them.
Ignore him, the bastard.
BILL hesitates, but a withering look from DAWN keeps him course. BRUCE levels with them. He calls across thirty ya of river.
Dan! It's me!
She refuses even to acknowledge him. Under her breath, sh instructs BILL.
Keep going. Stay on this bank.
BILL whips up speed, keeping to the opposite side of the river from BRUCE, who wades out up to his knees and holds his arms, pleadingly.
Give me a chance to explain.
SUE waves at him. DAWN glowers at her.
I'm going to kill you, Sue Rohan.

Fully clothed, his khaki cap perched on his head, BRUCE s out towards the punt. By the time he reaches the middle o the river, they are fifty years upstream. BRUCE swims bac the shore. Dripping wet, he runs up the riverbank until h well ahead of the punt and plunges in again. This time, h course coincides with the punt. He grabs the side of the and hangs on, out of breath.
Couldn't write...secret posting...came as soon as I heard about the baby.
DAWN grabs a paddle and forces him under the water. He po up further down the boat.
I went AWOL to be with you. I'm a deserter.
She cracks the paddle over his head. He sinks under the water, his cap floats away. BILL rescues it. BRUCE does n reappear. They wait, become alarmed. DAWN kneels down, pe into the water.
Oh, Bruce, Bruce. What have I done?
His head pops up inches from her face. Levering himself u the boat, he kisses her on the mouth. She grabs his hair smothering him with kisses.
I missed you so much.
BILL and SUE exchange disgusted looks.

They are all gathered together. GRANDFATHER GEORGE, GRAND GRACE, HOPE, CHARITY, BILL and SUE. CLIVE, in uniform, gi his daughter way. MAC and MOLLY are together again All witness the quiet, subdued marriage of DAWN and BRUCE. Th only guests are two military POLICEMEN sit in the back. T appear to be ordinary soldiers until they step outside th church and put their red caps on.

The bridal pair come out and the VICAR, considerably embarrassed, makes his excuses and backs away. A picture taken. The REDCAPS seize BRUCE by each arm. DAWN clings t him, a last kiss, and he is borne away. They all stand at church doors waving to him as he is driven away in a jeep There is some dutiful sniffing from the women, but since seems quite happy, there is no need for sympathetic tears GRACE impulsively hugs MOLLY.
I'm so glad you could come. Here we are, all together again.
Happy as can be. In the old groove.
CLIVE shakes MAC's hand warmly.
So you're going to be a grandfather.
And I'm still just a lad myself.
Don't bother to grow up. It's no fun at all.

The party is on the veranda. BILL and SUE sit on the step GRANDFATHER is alone on the swing seat. GRACE and her thr sisters are a sting quartet. They finish a piece. The oth clap. It leaves them a little melancholy.
What can you do with four daughters, I asked myself, A string quartet was all I could come up with. They hated me for making them learn.
And now we're glad you did.
CLIVE raises his glass. He is tipsy.
Here's to music. And absent friends.
And absent bridegrooms!
And the bride.
The bride.
And here's to my CO. He's wangled me a posting close to home. He said your house burns down, your daughter gets married, you're always on compassionate leave. You might as well stay down there!
There are cries of congratulations and encouragement.
I've found a bungalow to rent up the towpath, Clive. I never want to leave the river again. The children have had such a wonderful summer.
Fair enough. (raises glass) The river.
The river.
And loyal friends.
He tips his glass at MAC, who squirms a little. The drink made CLIVE sound excessively sincere and sentimental, so so that if he were sober, it might seem like irony.
...and good and faithful wives.
He points his glass at MOLLY and GRACE and waves it at th sisters and DAWN.
We hope, and trust.
He laughs, and the others join in, an awkward moment. GRA and MOLLY catch each others eye.
And grumpy grandfathers.
Since you are shortly to join our ranks, I throw down the gauntlet. A cricket match. You and Mac against Bill and me. Back garden.
The three men and one boy rise to the challenge and file the side of the house to the lawn at the back.
You know Mac played for Surrey Seconds, and I opened for the Indian Army. Are you sure...
GRANDFATHER GEORGE waves his objection aside.
(to Clive, an aside) It's an olive branch. Take it. It's the best he can do.
We're putting you in to bat.

He hands CLIVE the bat, and flips the ball to BILL with a broad wink. CLIVE takes guard against the apple tree, whi is now heavy with fruit. BILL bowls. The ball turns, beat the bat. MAC pats down the grass where the ball bounced.
Fine delivery, Bill, Good length. Turned a bit too.
GRANDFATHER GEORGE hands the ball back to BILL and nudges him.
(whispering) Give him the you-know-what.
Very well, Grandpa.
BILL delivers his googly. It bamboozles is father who pop caught and bowled. CLIVE is startled. As MAC takes the ba CLIVE offers a warning.
I think it was a googly.

MAC takes guard. BILL Bowls. He plays forward, smothering spin. Still no run. The next ball is pitched short. MAC p back, waits for the ball to break in from the leg which i does more sharply than he expects. He just manages to dig out. The next is the googly. MAC does not spot it. It cut from the off and clean bowls him. GRANDFATHER GEORGE cack triumphantly.
Googly. You didn't spot it either.
I taught him how and now he turns it against me.
The law of life. Cruel, isn't it?
The wicked old bugger.
This boy will make his way in the world.
GRANDFATHER GEORGE slaps BILL on the back with such enthusiasm that he sends the boy sprawling. CLIVE catches him, holds him close and whispers in his ear.
I'm proud of you.
Cries of alarm come from the house. CLIVE hears his name called. They hurry back.
The men arrive to find the women in a state of alarm. The are gathered in a knot around DAWN. BILL pushes his way forward.
Clive, go for the doctor. It's Dawn. She's in labour.
BILL peers between the women and catches a glimpse of DAW standing arched against a chair, one hand supporting the baby's head which has appeared between her legs.
Hot water! Lots of hot water!
What for?
I don't know. They always say that at the pictures.
He rushes out.
CLIVE runs down to veranda steps.
She just went to the toilet, and it came out.
MAC joins CLIVE and they run to the boat and fumble awkwa with the oars.
GRACE tries to be calm. She holds DAWN gingerly.
Now take deep breaths, and push.
Why? It's coming on its own. It doesn't hurt.
BILL comes to SUE's side and they catch another glimpse o the baby's head. SUE wrinkles her nose.
It's all sticky.
BILL passes clean out and crumples to the floor.
BILL is running flat out, running for his life. He passes blurred orchard, a garden, a park.
BILL, still running hard, looks over his shoulder and tur in to a bungalow that faces on to the river.

The living room is cheerful and spacious. Out of the wind the sun sets over the river. DAWN breast-feeds the baby, a week or two old. GRACE knits a tiny pair of leggings. S is drawing a picture. CLIVE snoozes in an armchair. They listening to Churchill on the wireless.
...it is not the end. It is not the beginning.
BILL enters, flushed and panting. His eyes are bright wit excitement. He goes to DAWN and, reaching inside his shir pulls out a peach and hands it to her reverentially.
I scrumped it. I nearly got caught. They chased me for ages.

DAWN take's it. It looks pretty miserable. Most of the fu skin has rubbed off during its hazardous journey next to BILL's skin. DAWN's first impulse is to make a sarcastic comment, but in her new maturity, she bites it back and smiles.
You did that for me, and on the last day of your holidays?
(blushing) Well, for the baby, really.
Thank you Billy, from the baby and me.

GRANDFATHER GEORGE drives his old Armstrong Siddeley Sapp along the river towpath. Beside him sits a very morose BI wearing  a school cap, with a satchel, gasmask, and a suitcase on his lap. GRANDFATHER GEORGE adjusts the advance/retard lever and glares at the sullen boy.
You miserable little tripe-hound. I'm the one who should be fed up, sacrificing my last sup of black market petrol to take you to school.
I have to live in Rosehill Avenue as well.
Only till they get you into the local school.
With Mrs. Evans. I hate her.
You'll be at home for the weekends. Now shut up, or walk.
They pass a film unit setting up equipment on the river b Extras dressed as soldiers - Germans, British, American - lounge, smoke and drink tea.
Strapping fellows playing silly buggers with a war on. Outrageous.
BILL cranes back watching as long as he can.

The car draws up outside the school entrance. A grim wall surrounds the institution and BILL gets out, head hung lo and walks towards the gate as though to the gallows. GRANDFATHER GEORGE watches from the car. He grips the steering wheel angrily. A teacher strides past. GRANDFATH GEORGE shouts after him out of the window.
All you do is knock the sense out of them and fill them up with muck.

As BILL enters, he is astonished to see hundreds of child in a state of delirious celebration. Boys fling their cap the air. They cheer. They whoop. They run amok. Behind th lie the smouldering ruins of the school. BILL cheers loud than anyone. He remembers his grandfather, turns on his h and runs back to the road.
GRANDFATHER GEORGE is awkwardly turning the car in the ro He drives off. BILL runs flat out and comes up to the win shouting.
Grandpa! There's no school! It's been hit by a bomb!
GRANDFATHER GEORGE slows up.
I have to hand it to you, Bill, you come up with some good ones. Go back and take your medicine.

He drives off leaving BILL stranded. A fire engine and AR vehicles race up to the school. They pass GRANDFATHER GEO and doubt shows in is face. He stops, gets out. Boys are spilling out of school, cheering. BILL runs up to him.
It's true.
You're much more convincing when you're making it up.
They get into the car.
Grandpa, if you think of something hard enough, can you make it happen?
Apparently so.
A barking laugh wells up and escapes his throat. It burst forth in great waves like a flood that has been dammed up years.
GRANDFATHER GEORGE's laugh, and BILL's too, ring out over autumn river which beckons to BILL with the promise of st days.
